title: EU Statement on the 2nd day of the 13th Trade Policy Review of the European Union, 07 July 2017
text: Mr Chairman, Mr Discussant, Distinguished Delegates, INTRODUCTION 1. I would like to use my intervention and the time available to engage systematically with all the comments and issues raised in the oral statements made on Wednesday. More questions have come in since then. We will reply to all outstanding questions within the deadline foreseen for this exercise. 2. I welcome the positive statements made on Wednesday and this morning, the vast majority of which emphasised the EU's openness and support for the multilateral trading system as well as our efforts to lead by example in the face of a growing backlash against globalisation and the risk of protectionism. I also welcome the multiple statements that have been made highlighting that the vast majority of trade with the EU is conducted in fact without any problems and that potential concerns are very much an exception rather than the rule. They are in fact limited to certain well defined areas.3. Many Members also recognise our efforts to push forward preparations for a successful MC11. Indeed, a successful Ministerial Conference in Buenos Aires is a top priority for the EU and we have made every effort to make this objective a reality. 4. I'm happy to use this opportunity to confirm also the very positive news coming out of Brussels that the EU and Japan have indeed reached a political agreement on a free trade agreement which has every potential to redefine and significantly expand our trade relations. The deal shows that there is scope for ambitious, comprehensive and mutually beneficial bilateral trade agreements that are fully compatible with the WTO.5. Several Members commended the EU for the value-based trade agenda set out in our Trade for All strategy and I am very happy with this positive reaction. Our efforts in this area highlight an important point: that trade is of mutual benefit and that we all stand to gain from trade which is fair and sustainable. This extends also to the issue of gender equality and women's empowerment, to which we attach great importance and on which we would like to see more activities in the WTO. The next opportunity in this regard will be next week's Aid for Trade Global Review.6. I will now answer the questions you raised on Wednesday and this morning as follows: I will start with a few more systemic issues, before moving to the specific questions, again under the 10 blocks. SYSTEMIC ISSUES 7. The implementation of the Agreements reached in Bali and in Nairobi is now a key concern and I'm happy to confirm that the EU is in the forefront of these efforts. Specifically on export competition, it is well known that the EU has not provided export subsidies since 2013. We are now finalising the preparation of a revised EU schedule that will bring our entitlements effectively to zero. This will be put forward to the Membership in the coming weeks. We call on other concerned Members to do the same in order to formalise the commitments made in Nairobi. 8. Over the last year, the EU has made clear its expectations for a substantive and meaningful outcome at MC11. We have supported this with concrete submissions on most of the areas under discussion. We commend all of you who have done the same. Now, true negotiations need to begin quickly. I would call on all Members to avoid tactical games and focus on substance, which is the only way we can work towards concrete outcomes in Buenos Aires. 9. For the EU, the outcome of MC11 as well as post-MC11 work is closely linked to our long-term objective of levelling the playing field by creating new rules in areas which are in dire need of new disciplines. This particularly includes the broad area of subsidies. In this regard, some Members referred in their statements to export credits and the very important work being done by the International Working Group (IWG), which brings together many participants including the EU, China, Brazil, India, South Africa and the US to pursue the shared goal of developing new export credit disciplines. What we are talking about here is clarifying the rules regarding prohibited export subsidies and ensuring that the major providers of export credits are in fact playing by the rules.10. One Member (China) referred to the EU's restrictions on exports of high-tech goods, particularly dual-use goods which can be used for both civilian and military applications. The EU implements its policies in this area within the clearly set limits of UN Security Council resolutions, WTO agreements and the cooperation that we have with numerous other Members in international export control regimes. Every export transaction is assessed on its own merits taking into account the risk that a particular item will be diverted to military end-use. I would underline that this well established policy does not in fact create any meaningful problems for legitimate transactions. What actually creates problems are efforts to divert civilian technologies toward military programmes and forced technology transfers.11.  The discussant and a few Members referred to some delays with regard to EU notifications. Allow me to reiterate that the EU treats transparency and notifications extremely seriously. Several EU notifications were actually made in recent weeks. These covered an STE corrigendum, our notification on Rules of Origin for LDCs as well as our GPA statistics. Regarding our domestic support notifications, it is well known that financing cycles vary across WTO Members and that they do not necessarily end on 31 December of each year. The last DS:1 notification by the EU covered the calendar year 2013-2014 and we are close to finalising the one for the 2014-2015 calendar year. Unfortunately the same cannot be said for every WTO Member, some of whom have not submitted the necessary notifications since the creation of this organisation in 1995. I would refer Members here to the useful compilation prepared by the Secretariat [document G/L/223/Rev.24]. 12. And finally, a few Members referred to the EU's tariff profile, mentioning explicitly our tariffs for agricultural and fish products. Some of you have higher agricultural tariffs while others have very high industrial ones. While tariff liberalisation efforts have been undertaken recently through bilateral and plurilateral tracks, such efforts have not been undertaken recently in the WTO. Future adjustments of Members' tariff structures need to take place within the context of comprehensive market access negotiations, on which we sadly do not sense much appetite in this organisation. ***13. I would now proceed to addressing some of the more specific issues raised, organised again into 10 blocks. Block 1 - Agriculture: 14. Firstly, on agriculture issues, I noted several interventions by Members, relating to the three pillars and welcoming the continuous process of CAP reform: domestic support, market access and export competition.15. Let me start by domestic support. 16. The decline in the use of public intervention operated by the EU is a result of the change in policy orientation of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) from product (price) support (through market intervention measures) towards producer support through direct income support. Reforms of the CAP since the early 1990s have changed the public intervention policy, decreasing both the administered prices and buying in quantities and completely eliminating the system for some products. 17. This trend is reflected in the changes in the structure of the CAP budget where the share of market intervention measures (including export refunds) declined from 100% of total CAP expenditure in 1980 to below 5% in 2011. Is also reflected in the EU's notified domestic support where the current total Aggregated Measure Support (AMS) has decreased dramatically. Today, market intervention measures can only be used as a safety net mechanism. It was in this sense that the mechanism was triggered in 2014 and 2015, but only, for certain fruit and vegetables, in response to the Russian import ban and in reaction to the dramatic global price fall for dairy products.18. Most CAP support is notified as Green Box compliant decoupled income support, which is granted to farmers in the form of decoupled direct payments with no obligation to produce. The latest "DS:1 notification" of the EU reported very limited support in the Amber Box (less than € 6 bn, 95% of which was for Market Price Support to wheat, butter and skimmed milk powder).19. In addition, I would like to refer to the end of the last two remaining production quotas in the CAP for milk and sugar, both of which are supressed. As a consequence, EU prices will align even further with world prices. 20. In the light of these developments and the EU's efforts over the years, I would emphasise my expectation and hope that other WTO Members would undertake the same level of reforms in agriculture.21. Some delegations referred to the fact that EU subsidies under the Amber Box have not decreased based on OECD data. I would like to underline that the OECD methodology is quite different from the logic of the WTO Agreement on Agriculture. I strongly believe that policies conducted under the WTO Agreement on Agriculture and reviewed in the TPR, should be assessed under WTO criteria. And here the trend is crystal clear – an enormous shift has occurred in recent years from EU Amber Box support to non-trade distorting Green Box support. Some Members may call this box shifting. I rather call this "good policy" which is in the EU's interest and in your interest. To summarise: you should ask yourselves whether you would prefer Members who still maintain high levels of trade distorting Amber Box support to maintain such measures or would you prefer that they move toward non-trade distorting Green Box support. The answer I think is clear.22. In relation to market access in agriculture, I think it is important to emphasise that the EU is today the world's largest importer of agriculture products, with imports of more than € 112 bn in 2016.  In addition, the EU has concluded and continues to negotiate ambitious FTA agreements to reduce agricultural tariffs in bilateral trade.23. The EU import regime for agricultural products is fully transparent and predictable and is contained in the EU's schedule, as accepted and bound as part of the Uruguay Round Agreement.  The EU has only a limited number of tariff peaks, which were accepted and bound as part of the Uruguay Round Agreement. 24. With regard to TRQ management and concerns on low fill rates, I would like to clarify that those may result from market conditions such as competitive domestic production. Several of these TRQs presenting an under fill rate below 65%, are already managed on a first-come-first-served basis in line with the decision taken in Bali. TRQs including fill rates as well as TRQs managed by licenses are notified each year to the WTO. 25. New Zealand mentioned in its statement its concerns regarding tariffs on dairy products. I commend New Zealand for taking the time to convert some of our 'specific' tariffs into ad valorem equivalents. I would highlight in response that no changes have actually occurred to our specific tariffs for the goods concerned. These are in fact bound in our schedule. Any changes that New Zealand has recorded must therefore be the result of external factors such as the value of the imported product or the relevant exchange rate. 26. In relation to export competition, EU legislation is already in full compliance with the Nairobi outcome. As mentioned, no agricultural export subsidies have been granted since July 2013. Block 2 - Fisheries: 27. Secondly, on our Common Fisheries Policy, I am pleased to note that there was a general recognition of the EU's 2013 reform as a step in the right direction, towards greater sustainability and science based management of the resources. 28. The EU is dedicated to addressing the issue of excess of capacity that is also set out in SDG 14.6. I am very pleased to mention today that the EU has just submitted a revision of its original fisheries subsidies proposal to the Rules Negotiating Group in view of MC11. 29. I have noted Iceland's comment regarding our fish tariffs, the average of which is 12%. As mentioned in the general part of my statement, further tariff concessions should be the subject of comprehensive tariff negotiations. Unilateral “disarmament” of tariffs is not an option at this stage. Block 3 - Trade defence: 30. Third, several important questions were raised regarding our trade defence measures.31. In a world where a level playing field is a distant dream, where dumping is more common that we would like, and where massive amount of subsidies are threatening the competitiveness of our businesses and leading to overcapacity, trade defence will remain an integral and necessary part of our trade policy. Such tools will remain in place and will continue to be used until others reign in their policies.32. China referred in its statement to the need to live up to commitments. I fully agree and the EU has taken the necessary steps to fulfil its obligations. The issue is now subject to dispute settlement, so it would be inappropriate to comment further apart from saying that the EU will vigorously and staunchly defend its legislation. I would refer here again to compliance with notification obligations regarding subsidies being provided by Members. In the case of China, the last notification was made in 2015 and covered the period 2009-2014, and even this in a non-exhaustive manner. 33. Several questions were also raised regarding the Commission's capacity to self-initiate anti-dumping investigations. The EU's legal framework indeed provides for the possibility for the Commission to initiate anti-dumping investigations itself without having received a complaint. If the level of evidence available to the Commission is comparable to the level of evidence which would be required from a complainant to justify the initiation of an anti-dumping investigation. In practice, it is exceptional that the Commission initiates anti-dumping cases by itself.      34. A few Members also asked questions regarding amendments to our anti-dumping and anti-subsidy regulations. Here we have on the table our 2013 TDI modernisation proposal and the more recent 2016 proposal on the methodology to calculate dumping. The legislative process on both proposals is ongoing in the Council and European Parliament. I hope that agreement on the revisions will be reached by the end of the year. Block 4 – Investment: 35. Fourth, a few Members referred to the EU's investment policy and to the need to ensure clarity and legal certainty with regard to the 1400 existing BITs. This is a very valid point which the EU takes very seriously. 36. Since foreign direct investment policy is an integral part of the EU's common commercial policy, new investment negotiations with third countries should generally only be carried out at EU level. In order to ensure stability, the existing BITs between EU Member States and third countries remain in force and will continue to be preserved until they are replaced by EU agreements. 37. Finally, some Members rightly pointed to the need for clarity and predictability regarding the question of exclusive EU competence in view of the recent ECJ opinion on the Singapore case. The Court's ruling indeed provided clarity to on the issue of EU competences on trade and investment. The details were set out in my statement on Wednesday and in several responses to your written questions. Today, I would emphasise that while I understand that this is an important issue, it is in fact an issue of internal EU governance. It will not affect the fact that you will continue to negotiate with the European Union. Block 5 - SPS and TBT: 38. Five, with regard to SPS and TBT issues, I want to thank the Discussant, Canada, and other Members who acknowledged the improvements we have made to our legislation – particularly on animal and plant health. 39. Some of you commented on our use of risk assessment. EU SPS measures are science-based and they are adopted in accordance with the internationally recognised principles of risk analysis. The EU's risk assessor, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) is an independent source of scientific advice on risks associated with the food chain. The risk managers (European Commission, the European Parliament and the EU Member States) then adopt the appropriate risk management decisions on the basis of EFSA's risk assessments.40. Concerning the maximum residue limits (MRLs) for pesticides, the EU sets MRLs as low as reasonably achievable for the protection of consumers. This means that if a substance is not approved in the EU, the MRLs for the substance are set at the level of detection. The EU has circulated an information note to all WTO Members explaining in detail the process of applying import tolerances.41.  Concerning endocrine disruptors, the regulatory process for the adoption of the draft criteria to identify endocrine disruptors in chemical substances is ongoing. Discussions on the proposal providing for a derogation possibility from the criteria (i.e. the modification from 'negligible exposure' to 'negligible risk') will be resumed once the criteria have been adopted. This is an ongoing process in the EU with no final decision yet adopted. 42. On GMOs, I am happy to say that the system has actually accelerated over the last year and that the Commission is looking at the existing procedures to improve the efficiency and transparency of the process. In 2016 there were 11 new authorisations. 10 of these were for imported food and feed uses, and 1 for cut flowers. I would also like to highlight, that on 4 July 2017 the Commission adopted five more authorisations for GMOs for food and feed use: 2 GM cottons, 2 new GM maizes and the renewal of one GM maize.  43. There were also a number of very specific questions on SPS matters. I will try to answer these briefly here and suggest that the individual countries concerned follow up, if necessary, with the EU Delegation in the margins of the SPS Committee which meets here next week.44. Firstly, India mentioned anthroquinone in tea and reported that EU consumers were being deprived of the wonderful taste of Darjeeling. It has not yet been demonstrated whether the residues of anthraquinone found in tea are due to its unauthorised use as a pesticide, or because of inappropriate processing, or even because of environmental contamination. Based on scientific evidence, we doubled the MRL for anthroquinone in tea in 2015. The EU is ready to assist non-EU countries on the analytical methods or on any other technical information that would be needed to achieve the level of residues requested by us. This offer was already expressed to Chinese and Indian authorities in 2015 and 2016, respectively. I would also refer to our written answers to questions 22-24 from Indonesia on this point.45. Secondly, both Vietnam and India asked about the basis for our setting an MRLs for tricyclazole in rice. In 2015, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) published a Peer review on the substance in which the non-renewal of the substance was suggested. On the basis of this assessment, the EU decided to set the MRL at the default level of 0.01 mg/kg. In so doing, we recognised the specific growing conditions for basmati rice and delayed the entry of force of the new MRL to accommodate that. And, as I mentioned a moment ago, the EU is ready to assist non-EU countries on the analytical methods or on any other technical information that would be needed to reach the residues levels required by us. 46. Thirdly, Nepal asked if we could have reduced SPS requirements for LDCs. Here the EU is committed to act in line with Article 10 of the SPS Agreement concerning special and differential treatment. The EU is also a major provider of technical assistance to help LDCs build their SPS capacities but there cannot be a general exemption for LDCs.  47. Fourthly, Peru had asked why foods that were not on the EU market in May 1997 were subject to the EU Novel Foods Regulations. The new novel food regulation provides for a simplified procedure for placing on the EU market traditional foods from third countries. This procedure provides a faster and more proportionate safety assessment and allows traditional biodiversity foods to be authorised in the EU by a simple notification once the history of safe use in at least one non-EU country has been demonstrated. This is an important improvement to the current situation where such traditional foods need to undergo the full authorisation procedure. 48. I would now like to come back to the discussant's question regarding the compliance of the EU with TBT obligations, in particular his reference to the need to wait for six months (following the date that it has been notified to the TBT Committee) before adopting a draft measure. Allow me to clarify: the TBT Agreement does not entail an obligation for a six month waiting period between the notification of a draft measure and its adoption. Article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, the transparency cornerstone on TBT notifications, refers only to an obligation to notify draft measures with a significant effect on trade which are not based on an international standard. There is no 6-month requirement. The Appellate Body has never pronounced on any time requirement with regard to Art. 2.9.2. It has, however, pronounced on a 6-month requirement for Art. 2.12 in US-Clove Cigarettes, to which we consider the discussant hints at; but that requirement concerns the "reasonable interval" between publication and entry into force. 49. Regarding the US remark that EU assistance to third countries would be conditioned on the recipient's acceptance of EU standards, I would have to disagree. We have received several questions on this issue from the US and provided written replies. It is clear that our European neighbours naturally consider regional integration with the EU as being conducive to their economic development and applying EU standards is a logical means to ensuring simplified access to the EU market. History shows that all countries which have either joined the EU as full Members or integrated to some extent with the EU Single Market have benefitted from it in terms of their economic growth. Block 6: Sustainable development, environment and climate: 50. Six, many Members referred to the EU's focus on sustainable development and our position on environmental and climate issues.51. Here, I would recall that sustainability remains a top priority for EU trade policy. The EU will continue to reinforce its agenda to promote sustainable development, human rights and good governance, in the spirit of the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. We will continue to focus on environmental and climate priorities, and support eligible developing countries through our GSP scheme. 52. We welcome the numerous expressions of support made by Members regarding further progress in EGA negotiations. The EU remains committed to this process and calls on involved Members to properly re-engage to bring negotiations to a successful close. On climate issues, the EU remains fully and unequivocally committed to implementing the Paris Climate Convention.53. With regard to the EU's duty-free quota-free scheme for LDCs exports, which is known as the Everything But Arms initiative, I would like to recall that it is the most advanced, ambitious and far-reaching unilateral preference given by any Member to the LDCs. There are currently 49 beneficiaries of the scheme. 54. As mentioned in my opening statement, the EU has a comprehensive policy of providing support to developing countries and particularly the LDCs. Unilateral concessions are one element; our broad Aid for Trade and development aid scheme constitute another. Block 7 - Customs: 55. Seven, numerous comments were made about the Union Customs Code and the implementation of the Trade Facilitation Agreement.56. The EU is a staunch supporter of the Trade Facilitation Agreement. We continue to be strongly committed to assisting developing countries implement the agreement. Hence, we will continue to provide technical and financial assistance to make this objective a reality.57. The EU remains dedicated to introducing further improvements in our customs regime. The new Union Customs Code (UCC) responds to this objective. It aims to address the challenges of today including increasing trade volumes and value chains by providing tools that simplify customs procedures. The UCC takes an important step forward in the direction of ensuring uniform application of customs rules, within nevertheless the context of an EU system composed of 28 separate customs administrations. Block 8 - IPR: 58. Eight, on intellectual property, the discussant and some Members have noted the impact which imports of counterfeit and pirated goods have on the EU market and emphasized the general need to address infringements of intellectual property rights in the online environment, in particular as regards copyrights. Let me assure you that important work was undertaken to further modernize the legislative framework for copyright protection and enforcement with a particular focus on copyright-protected goods in the online environment. For this purpose, a number of legislative proposals were submitted by the European Commission in September 2016. Meanwhile, work progressed also on the review of the IPR enforcement regime in the EU, again with a particular focus on the need to adapt the regime to respond to challenges in the online environment. In recognition of the key role that intellectual property rights play in the EU economy, we remain fully committed to continue our efforts in this regard.59. There have also been questions raised on the EU trademark reform package and the possibility to interrupt goods in transit in the EU, in particular as regards generic medicines. Let me first clarify that the new rules do not raise obstacles to legitimate trade in non-infringing goods, including legitimately traded generic medicines. The new trademark provisions on goods in transit apply only in respect of goods which bear without authorisation a trademark which is identical with an EU trademark or which cannot be distinguished in its essential aspects from that trademark. The new rules do not apply to other intellectual property rights such as patents and designs.60. Regarding the statements made by delegates in relation to GIs, let me start by saying that the EU trade policy promotes protection of Geographical Indications in support of producers of products sold domestically and at international level. However, GIs are not an EU-only interest. Many countries, including developing countries, are convinced that GI protection adds value to the product. The EU system of GI protection is open to applications by third countries. 61. The reciprocal protection of GIs under bilateral trade agreements helps to secure the intellectual property rights of producers, prevents unfair competition, and meets consumer expectations for such products. It should also be noted that under such agreements, prior right holders' interests are respected and generic terms in either territory are excluded from protection. 62. In relation to the possible extension of GIs from agricultural to non-agricultural products, there is no final decision yet despite big interests by some trade partners. Block 9: - Single market and digital single market: 63. Nine, as also acknowledged by some of you on Wednesday, the Single Market is one of Europe’s greatest achievements, designed to allow goods, services, capital and people to move freely. Its effectiveness and preservation is at the heart of the European project and we are continuing working to adapt it to today's realities.  64. Among several actions under the Single Market Strategy, the European Commission has made it a priority to create a Digital Single Market. In particular, actions are taken for facilitating cross-border e-commerce, especially for SMEs, and to tackling geo-blocking: too many Europeans cannot use online services that are available in other EU countries; or they are re-routed to a local store with different and normally higher prices. These issues are still pending in the EU institutions. Block 10 - Services: 65. Regarding India's call for the EU Member States to implement the Intra-Corporate Transfer (ICT) directive, it is important to stress that several individual EU Member States already had national rules in place for admitting intra-corporate transferees and that the Directive simply replaces these with a harmonised, EU-wide scheme which simplifies and improves the situation as it offers mobility between EU Member States for non-EU staff (excluding UK, IE and DK that opted out). The Commission is actively monitoring the implementation of this important directive by Member States. Other issues: 66. Finally, before concluding, I would like to address a number of other specific issues that have been raised. 67. On government procurement, EU Member States publish on the Tenders Electronic Daily (TED) platform all contracts with a total value above the GPA thresholds. The contracting authority may also publish below thresholds contracts in TED on a voluntary basis.  This is the reason behind very different shares of a total member's procurement published in TED. 68. The rules for the EU's prior surveillance mechanism for certain steel products were discussed at length both at the Committee on Import Licensing and at the Committee on Safeguards. The purpose of this scheme is to collect information about the intention to import from all non-EU member countries (with the exception of Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein, members of the European Economic Area). This data is necessary to deal with the vulnerability of the EU steel market to sudden changes on world steel markets. 69. The prior surveillance regulation was recently amended to increase the exemption threshold up to 5000 kg for certain products. This will reduce the number of transaction falling under surveillance. Furthermore, the amended law explicitly encourages national authorities to accept handling the procedure in a paperless way. The European Commission is also working in parallel on a draft interpretative notice to respond to requests for clarification received from stakeholders and to ensure the uniform interpretation of existing surveillance rules.70. The discussant referred to the shipment of hazardous waste. The EU is fully in compliance with the Basel Convention and has set out a detailed legal framework for dealing with hazardous waste in the Waste Shipment Regulation. The EU has notified its scheme in its annual questionnaire on its import license procedures. The question raised – although legitimate in nature - does not therefore refer to our legal environment, but rather to enforcement activities. In this context, if the discussant or other WTO Members are in the possession of specific information regarding unlawful shipments, I would urge them to contact the relevant authorities in the EU. 71. Russia raised a question regarding unsafe third-country nuclear power plants. I have taken note of Russia's views regarding the written response provided. I would however reiterate that the question relates to a measure taken only very recently and that the EU's principles regarding transparency, due process and the rule of law actually require minimum of time to investigate the matter. 72. With regard to Russia's question on the North Stream 2 pipeline, the Commission has not disputed that the EU Gas Directive from 2009 does not explicitly apply to offshore parts of pipelines bringing gas from third countries to the EU, even though the Commission has expressed on many occasions that this project is not in line with the EU's Energy Union objectives and it does not therefore see the need for new gas infrastructure projects of such magnitude. I would add that on 9 June 2017, the Commission submitted to the Council a recommendation for a mandate to enter into negotiations with the Russian Federation on the conclusion of an international agreement concerning North Stream 2, which would ensure that the project is not operated in a legal void or according to a third country's energy laws only. 73. With regard to Russia's questions on autonomous measures for Ukraine, these were taken in the context of our bilateral trade liberalisation efforts, which are compatible with GATT Article XXIV. Our recent measures were driven by the fact that Ukraine could not fully profit from our DCFTA given the disruption and extraordinary fall in the GDP of Ukraine in 2014 and 2015.  74. And finally, many Members expressed their concerns and wishes regarding the Brexit issue. Here I would reiterate what we have said in our written responses. 75. Following the UK Government's formal notification to the European Council of its intention to withdraw from the EU, negotiations have now started. Until its withdrawal, the UK remains a Member State of the European Union with all rights and obligations of a Member State. We will revert to the WTO Membership at an appropriate moment in the future after engaging with the UK bilaterally. ***76. Finally, I would take this opportunity to thank you once again for all the comments made and questions raised. The EU considers this exercise to be important for broader transparency in this organisation. Nevertheless, we should remember that the TPR is not the only occasion for a frank discussion. Numerous points made over the last few days could equally well be addressed by experts in the context of the WTO's regular committee work. I would urge Members to fully engage in these regular discussions. I would  further ask that Members take the time to get acquainted with the written responses that we have provided and will provide to the well over 1000 questions we have received for this TPR. 77. The EU is committed to making the TPR process effective and useful. We have made several suggestions on how this could be achieved during the latest TPRM appraisal. We would encourage Members to also look for possible ways of further improving the process.78. The EU stands ready to provide further clarifications either today or in the future. Thank you. Geneva

title: The European Union backs the Kyrgyz Bar's  strategy to protect lawyers' rights and increase ethical standards
text: On 30 June 2017, Osh will host a round table «On the protection of lawyers’ rights and ethical standards of the legal profession», organised by the EU-Central Asia Rule of Law Platform, in cooperation with the Kyrgyz and the Paris Bars. The objective of the round-table is to provide exposure to best European practices in the area of protection of the rights of lawyers and ethical standards and to propose related recommendations aimed both at lawyers themselves and at decision makers, and the public in general. The round-table would therefore contribute to reinforcing the independence of lawyers and to strengthening the rule of law in the Kyrgyz Republic. Experts from France, Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic will engage in a dialogue and will exchange information on the laws and practices of their countries, with emphasis of relevant case law of the European Court of Human Rights. Co-chaired by Board Members of the Kyrgyz and the Paris Bars, the round-table will pursue the cooperation between the Kyrgyz and Paris Bars initiated with the signing of a Partnership Agreement in October 2015, under the auspices of the Rule of Law Platform. The Partnership Agreement’s objective is for the two Bars to support each other and their Members, on all matters of mutual interest relating to the exercise of the profession of lawyer, the development of the law and practice pertaining to the rule of law and the administration of justice and substantive developments in the law itself, both in France and Kyrgyzstan and at international level. As emphasised by EU High Representative/Vice-President Federica Mogherini, “defendants should be granted full access to full defense rights.” Core principles regulating the legal profession are the basis of the deontology of the European legal profession, and which contribute to shaping the European but also the Central Asian lawyer. They are essential to the newly-established legal professions of Central Asia that are struggling to establish their independence; and to increase understanding among lawyers of the importance of the lawyer’s role in society. The EU-Central Asia Rule of Law Platform project acts as a support mechanism to facilitate policy dialogue and promote the measures contributing to legal reforms in each of the Central Asian countries. The Platform is being funded by the European Union to the amount of EUR 1.8 million and is implemented by IBF International Consulting.  Osh

title: Russia: EU prolongs economic sanctions by six months
text: On 28 June 2017, the Council prolonged economic sanctions targeting specific sectors of the Russian economy until 31 January 2018 . This decision follows an update from President Macron and Chancellor Merkel to the European Council of 22-23 June 2017 on the implementation of the Minsk Agreements. This paved the way for the renewal of sanctions for a further six months. The Council formalised this decision today by written procedure and, in line with the rule for all such decisions, unanimously . The measures were originally introduced on 31 July 2014 for one year in response to Russia's actions destabilising the situation in Ukraine. They were strengthened in September 2014. They target the financial, energy and defence sectors, and the area of dual-use goods . On 19 March 2015, the European Council agreed to link the duration of the sanctions to the complete implementation of the Minsk agreements, which was foreseen to take place by 31 December 2015. Since this did not happen, and given that the Minsk agreements have still not been fully implemented, the Council has extended the sanctions.
